lesson.name: Lesson 7.12: Graphing the Standard Form, Part 1

page.title: 7.12.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will experiment with the graphs of quadratic functions expressed in standard form and reason about how the parameters of the expressions—specifically the coefficient of the squared term and the constant term—relate to features of the graphs.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain how the \(a\) and \(c\) in \(ax^2+bx+c\) affect the graph of the equation.
  • Explain how graphs, tables, and equations that represent the same quadratic function are related.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.12.1: Using Coefficients and Constant Terms to Identify Graphs of Linear Equations
  • 7.12.2: Transformations with Quadratic Functions
    • 7.12.2: Self Check
    • 7.12.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.12.3: Understanding the Behaviors of a Graph in Relation to Its Quadratic Expression
    • 7.12.3: Self Check
    • 7.12.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.12.4: Representations of Quadratic Functions
    • 7.12.4: Self Check
    • 7.12.4: Additional Resources
  • 7.12.5: Identifying Graphs of Quadratic Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.12.6: Practice
  • 7.12.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.12.1: Using Coefficients and Constant Terms to Identify Graphs of Linear Equations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Graphs A, B, and C represent three linear equations:

\(y=2x+4\)

\(y=3-x\)

\(y=3x-2\)

Use the following graph to answer questions 1–3.

​ ​
  1. Which graph corresponds to equation \(y=2x+4\)?

Correct! The graph representing \(y=2x+4\) has a slope of 2 and intersects the \(y\)-axis at 4, so it is Graph B.

Incorrect. The correct answer is B.The graph representing \(y=2x+4\) has a slope of 2 and intersects the \(y\)-axis at 4, so it is Graph B.

​
  1. Which graph corresponds to equation \(y=3-x\)?

Correct! The graph representing \(y=3-x\) has a slope of -1 and intersects the \(y\)-axis at 3, so it is Graph A.

Incorrect. The correct answer is A.The graph representing \(y=3-x\) has a slope of -1 and intersects the \(y\)-axis at 3, so it is Graph A.

​ ​
  1. Which graph corresponds to equation \(y=3x-2\)?

Correct! The graph representing \(y=3x-2\) has a slope of 3 and intersects the \(y\)-axis at -2, so it is Graph C.

Incorrect. The correct answer is C.The graph representing \(y=3x-2\) has a slope of 3 and intersects the \(y\)-axis at -2, so it is Graph C.

page.title: 7.12.2: Transformations with Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph \(y=x^2\), and then experiment with each of the changes to the function in questions 1–7. Record your observations of what you noticed or wondered about each set of changes to the function (include sketches, if helpful).



  1. Add different constant terms to \(x^2\) (for example: \(x^2+5\), \(x^2+10\), \(x^2-3\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Changing the constant term either raised the graph (when the constant is positive) or lowered the graph (when the constant is negative). Adding the constant term shifted the graph vertically, but the overall shape of the graph did not change.


  1. Multiply \(x^2\) by different positive coefficients greater than 1 (for example: \(3x^2\), \(7.5x^2\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Multiplying \(x^2\) by different positive numbers changed the shape of the graph, making it "steeper" when the constant is larger and less steep when the constant is smaller. The size of the coefficient determined how much of a vertical stretch was applied to the graph.


  1. Multiply \(x^2\) by different negative coefficients less than or equal to -1 (for example: \(-x^2\),\(-4x^2\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Multiplying \(x^2\) by a negative number flipped the graph (or reflected the graph) over the \(x\)-axis so that it opens downward rather than upward.


  1. Multiply \(x^2\) by different coefficients between -1 and 1 (for example: \(12x^2\), \(-0.25x^2\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Multiplying \(x^2\) by numbers between -1 and 1 changed the opening of the graph as well as the direction of the graph. Shrinking the coefficient from 1 toward 0 made the graph "shallower" and wider. This change vertically compressed the graph. When the coefficient is 0, the graph becomes a horizontal line. Raising the coefficient from -1 to 0 had the same effect of vertically compressing the graph, except that the graph started out opening downward.


  1. Add different constants to \(x\) before squaring the term (for example \((x-1)^2\), \((x+2)^2\), \((x-3)^2\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

When a constant is added to the \(x\) in \(x^2\), the graph moves horizontally to the left. When a constant is subtracted from the \(x\) in \(x^2\), the graph moves horizontally to the right.


  1. Multiply \(x\) by different positive coefficients greater than 1 (for example: (\(3x)^2\), \((7.5x)^2\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Multiplying \(x\) by different positive numbers changed the shape of the graph, making it more narrow when the constant is larger and less narrow when the constant is smaller.


  1. Multiply \(x\) by different positive coefficients between 0 and 1 (for example: \((0.5x)^2\), \((0.1x)^2\)).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Multiplying \(x\) by different positive numbers between 0 and 1 changed the shape of the graph, making it wider as the decimal gets closer to zero.

For quadratics, the parent function is \(y=x^2\) . From there, any moves created by making changes to the function like in questions 1–7 above are called transformations.


Extending Your Thinking

Examine the graphs of three quadratic functions.

  1. What can you say about the coefficient of \(x^2\) in the expression that defines \(f\) (in black at the top)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is positive because the graph of \(f\) opens upward.

  1. What can you say about the coefficient of \(x^2\) in the expression that defines \(g\) (in blue in the middle)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is positive because the graph of \(g\) opens upward.

Or

The coefficient is less than the coefficient for the graph of \(f\) (but still greater than 0) because \(g\) is wider.

  1. What can you say about the coefficient of \(x^2\) in the expression that defines \(h\) (in yellow at the bottom)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is negative because the graph of \(h\) opens downward.

Or

The absolute value of the coefficient of \(h\) is less than the absolute value of the coefficients for both \(f\) and \(g\) because \(h\) is wider.

  1. How do each of the functions compare to each other?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The coefficients cannot be identified exactly without knowing the coordinates of some points on the graph. The coefficient of the squared term of \(f\) is greater than that of \(g\) because the graph of \(f\) is narrower, indicating that it is growing faster than the graph of \(g\). The absolute value of the coefficient of \(h\) is less than that of \(g\) because the graph of \(h\) is wider, indicating that it is not growing as quickly.

page.title: 7.12.2: Self Check
page.contents: How is the graph of \(f(x)=(x-4)^2\) transformed from the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would be \(x^2+4\). Subtracting a constant from \(x\) moves the graph of \(y = x^2\) that many places right. The answer is right 4.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would be \(x^2-4\). Subtracting a constant from \(x\) moves the graph of \(y = x^2\) that many places right. The answer is right 4.
That’s correct! Check yourself: When a constant is being subtracted from the \(x\) in the parent function, \(f(x)=x^2\), the graph moves horizontally to the right.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would be \((x+4)^2\). Subtracting a constant from \(x\) moves the graph of \(y = x^2\) that many places right. The answer is right 4.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.12.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Graphing Quadratic Functions Using Transformations

GRAPH A QUADRATIC FUNCTION OF THE FORM \(f(x)=x^2+k\) USING A VERTICAL SHIFT

The graph of \(f(x)=x^2+k\) shifts the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\) vertically \(k\) units.

  • If \(k > 0\), shift the parabola vertically up \(k\) units.
  • If \(k < 0\), shift the parabola vertically down \(\vert k\vert\) units.

GRAPH A QUADRATIC FUNCTION OF THE FORM \(f(x)=(x−h)^2\) USING A HORIZONTAL SHIFT

The graph of \(f(x)=(x−h)^2\) shifts the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\) horizontally \(h\) units.

  • If \(h > 0\), shift the parabola horizontally right \(h\) units.
  • If \(h < 0\), shift the parabola horizontally left \(\vert h\vert\) units.

GRAPH OF A QUADRATIC FUNCTION OF THE FORM \(f(x)=ax^2\)

The coefficient a in the function \(f(x)=ax^2\) affects the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\) by stretching or compressing it.

  • If \(0<|a|<1\), the graph of \(f(x)=ax^2\) will be “wider” than the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\).
  • If \(|a|>1\), the graph of \(f(x)=ax^2\) will be “skinnier” than the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\).

Try It: Graphing Quadratic Functions Using Transformations

How does the graph of \(f(x)=x^2+3\) change from \(f(x)=x^2\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine shifts in graphs:

The function \(f(x)=x^2\) is the parent function for quadratics. For \(f(x)=x^2+3\) , when 3 is added to \(f(x)=x^2\), the graph shifts up 3 units. This shift occurs because the value of 3 is being added to the output of the \(x^2\) function. Thus, the shift is seen vertically because it affects the output values.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.12.3: Understanding the Behaviors of a Graph in Relation to Its Quadratic Expression

Activity

  1. Use the table with different values of \(x\) to answer questions a–g for the values of \(x^2+10\). (You may also use a spreadsheet tool, if available.)

  1. When \(x=-3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((-3)^2+10=9+10=19\)

The correct answer is 19. \((-3)^2+10=9+10=19\)

  1. When \(x=-2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((-2)^2+10=4+10=14\)

The correct answer is 14. \((-2)^2+10=4+10=14\)

  1. When \(x=-1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((-1)^2+10=1+10=11\)

The correct answer is 11. \((-1)^2+10=1+10=11\)

  1. When \(x=0\) and \(x^2=0\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((0)^2+10=0+10=10\)

The correct answer is 10. \((0)^2+10=0+10=10\)

  1. When \(x=1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((1)^2+10=1+10=11\)

The correct answer is 11. \((1)^2+10=1+10=11\)

  1. When \(x=2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((2)^2+10=4+10=14\)

The correct answer is 14. \((2)^2+10=4+10=14\)

  1. When \(x=3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((3)^2+10=9+10=19\)

The correct answer is 19. \((3)^2+10=9+10=19\)

  1. When \(x=-3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(x^2-3\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((-3)^2-3=9-3=6\)

The correct answer is 6. \((-3)^2-3=9-3=6\)

  1. When \(x=-2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(x^2-3\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((-2)^2-3=4-3=1\)

The correct answer is 1. \((-2)^2-3=4-3=1\)

  1. When \(x=-1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(x^2-3\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((-1)^2-3=1-3=-2\)

The correct answer is -2. \((-1)^2-3=1-3=-2\)

  1. When \(x=0\) and \(x^2=0\), what is value of \(x^2-3\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((0)^2-3=0-3=-3\)

The correct answer is -3. \((0)^2-3=0-3=-3\)

  1. When \(x=1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(x^2-3\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(-2. (1)2-3=1-3=-2\)

The correct answer is -2. \(-2. (1)2-3=1-3=-2\)

  1. When \(x=2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(x^2-3\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((2)^2-3=4-3=1\)

The correct answer is 1. \((2)^2-3=4-3=1\)

  1. When \(x=3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(x^2+10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \((3)^2-3=9-3=6\)

The correct answer is 6. \((3)^2-3=9-3=6\)

  1. In the earlier activity “Transformations with Quadratic Functions,” you observed the effects on the graph of adding or subtracting a constant term from \(x^2\). Study the values in the table created from questions 1 and 2 in this activity. Use these values to explain why the graphs in the earlier activity changed the way they did when a constant term is added or subtracted.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

All values in the third row are 10 more than those in the second row, and all values in the last row are 3 less than those in the second row. This suggests that all the points that represent \(x^2+10\) are 10 units higher on the graph than those for \(x^2\), and all the points that represent \(x^2-3\) are 3 units lower than those for \(x^2\), which explains why the graphs move up or down when a constant term is added or subtracted.

  1. When \(x=-3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(-3)^2=2 \cdot 9=18\)

The correct answer is 18. \(2(-3)^2=2 \cdot 9=18\)

  1. When \(x=-2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(-2)^2=2 \cdot 4=8\)

The correct answer is 8. \(2(-2)^2=2 \cdot 4=8\)

  1. When \(x=-1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(-1)2=2 \cdot 1=2\)

The correct answer is 2. \(2(-1)2=2 \cdot 1=2\)

  1. When \(x=0\) and \(x^2=0\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(0)^2=2 \cdot 0=0\)

The correct answer is 0. \(2(0)^2=2 \cdot 0=0\)

  1. When \(x=1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(1)^2=2 \cdot 1=2\)

The correct answer is 2. \(2(1)^2=2 \cdot 1=2\)

  1. When \(x=2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(2)^2=2 \cdot 4=8\)

The correct answer is 8. \(2(2)^2=2 \cdot 4=8\)

  1. When \(x=3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(2x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(2(3)^2=2 \cdot 9=18\)

The correct answer is 18. \(2(3)^2=2 \cdot 9=18\)

  1. When \(x=-3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(-3)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 9=\frac{9}{2}=4\frac{1}{2}=4.5\)

The correct answer is 4.5. \(\frac{1}{2}(-3)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 9=\frac{9}{2}=4\frac{1}{2}=4.5\)

  1. When \(x=-2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(-2)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4=\frac{4}{2}=2\)

The correct answer is 2. \(\frac{1}{2}(-2)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4=\frac{4}{2}=2\)

  1. When \(x=-1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(-1)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1=\frac{1}{2}=0.5\)

The correct answer is 0.5. \(\frac{1}{2}(-1)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1=\frac{1}{2}=0.5\)

  1. When \(x=0\) and \(x^2=0\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(0)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 0=0\)

The correct answer is 0. \(\frac{1}{2}(0)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 0=0\)

  1. When \(x=1\) and \(x^2=1\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(1)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1=\frac{1}{2}=0.5\)

The correct answer is 0.5. \(\frac{1}{2}(1)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1=\frac{1}{2}=0.5\)

  1. When \(x=2\) and \(x^2=4\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(2)2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4=\frac{4}{2}=2\)

The correct answer is 2. \(\frac{1}{2}(2)2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4=\frac{4}{2}=2\)

  1. When \(x=3\) and \(x^2=9\), what is value of \(\frac{1}{2}x^2\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(\frac{1}{2}(3)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 9=\frac{9}{2}=4\frac{1}{2}=4.5\)

The correct answer is 4.5. \(\frac{1}{2}(3)^2=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 9=\frac{9}{2}=4\frac{1}{2}=4.5\)

  1. In the earlier activity “Transformations with Quadratic Functions,” you observed the effects on the graph of multiplying \(x^2\) by different coefficients. Study the values in the table created from questions 1 and 2 in this activity. Use these values to explain why the graphs in the earlier activity changed the way they did when \(x^2\) is multiplied by a number greater than 1, by a negative number less than or equal to -1, and by numbers between -1 and 1.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

When we multiply \(x^2\) by the positive coefficient 2, all the output values double. For any input value \(x\) , the output value of \(2x^2\) is twice as large as that of \(x^2\). So, the width of the graph becomes narrower because it grows faster. When we multiply \(x^2\) by a number between 0 and 1, the output values become smaller, so the graph becomes wider or vertically compressed. When we multiply by a negative number, all the positive values become negative, which reflects the direction of the opening of the graph from opening up to opening down.

Video: Understanding the Behaviors of a Graph in Relation to Its Quadratic Expression

Watch the following video to learn more about the behaviors of a graph in relation to its quadratic expression.

page.title: 7.12.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which curve is narrower than \(f(x)=x^2\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This will move the graph of f(x)=x2 up 3 (a vertical shift). The answer is \(f(x)=3x^2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Since the coefficient of \(f(x)=x^2\) is 3 and \(3>1\), this will make the graph narrower or skinnier than the parent graph \(f(x)=x^2\) (a vertical stretch).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This will make the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\) wider (a vertical compression). The answer is \(f(x)=3x^2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This will move the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\) to the left 3 (a horizontal shift). The answer is \(f(x)=3x^2\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.12.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing Transformations to Quadratic Graphs

Remember that the graph representing any quadratic function is a shape called a parabola. People often say that a parabola "opens upward" when the lowest point on the graph is the vertex (where the graph changes direction), and "opens downward" when the highest point on the graph is the vertex. Each coefficient in a quadratic expression written in standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) tells us something important about the graph that represents it.

The graph of \(y=x^2\) is a parabola opening upward with vertex at \((0,0)\). Adding a constant term 5 gives \(y=x^2+5\) and raises the graph by 5 units. Subtracting 4 from \(x^2\) gives \(y=x^2−4\) and moves the graph 4 units down.

\(x\)

-3

-2

-1

0

1

2

3

\(x^2\)

9

4

1

0

1

4

9

\(x^2+5\)

14

9

6

5

6

9

14

\(x^2-4\)

5

0

-3

-4

-3

0

5

A table of values can help us see that adding 5 to \(x^2\) increases all the output values of \(y=x^2\) by 5, which explains why the graph moves up 5 units. Subtracting 4 from \(x^2\) decreases all the output values of \(y=x^2\) by 4, which explains why the graph shifts down by 4 units.


In general, the constant term of a quadratic expression in standard form influences the vertical position of the graph. An expression with no constant term (such as \(x^2\) or \(x^2+9x\)) means that the constant term is 0, so the \(y\)-intercept of the graph is on the \(x\)-axis. It's not shifted up or down relative to the \(x\)-axis.


The coefficient of the squared term in a quadratic function also tells us something about its graph. The coefficient of the squared term in \(y=x^2\) is 1. Its graph is a parabola that opens upward.


Multiplying \(x^2\) by a number greater than 1 makes the graph steeper, so the parabola is narrower than that representing \(x^2\).

Multiplying \(x^2\) by a number less than 1 but greater than 0 makes the graph less steep, so the parabola is wider than that representing \(x^2\).

Multiplying x2 by a number less than 0 makes the parabola open downward.

\(x\)

-3

-2

-1

0

1

3

\(x^2\)

\(2x^2\)

18

2

0

2

8

18

\(-2x^2\)

-18

-8

-2

0

-2

-8

-18

If we compare the output values of \(2x^2\) and \(-2x^2\), we see that they are opposites, which suggests that one graph would be a reflection of the other across the \(x\)-axis.

Try It: Comparing Transformations to Quadratic Graphs

  1. If the red graph (in the middle) is the parent function, \(f(x)=x^2\), what are the equations of the blue graph (at the top) and green graph (at the bottom)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve to find the equations of the other graphs:

The green graph is the same as \(f(x)=x^2\) but is shifted down 2. The function will be \(f(x)=x^2-2\).
The blue graph is the same as \(f(x)=x^2\) but is shifted up 4. The function will be \(f(x)=x^2+4\).


  1. If the red graph (in the middle) is the parent function, \(f(x)=x^2\), what are the equations of the blue graph (to the right) and green graph (to the left)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve to find the equations of the other graphs.

The green graph is the same as \(f(x)=x^2\) but is shifted left \(\frac32\). The function will be \(f(x)=(x+\frac{3}{2})^2\).

The blue graph is the same as \(f(x)=x^2\) but is shifted right 3. The function will be \(f(x)=(x-3)^2\).


  1. The red graph (in the middle) is \(f(x)=x^2\). The equations of the other graphs are \(f(x)=\frac{1}{3}x^2\) and \(f(x)=5x^2\).

Which function matches the green graph (on the inside)? The blue graph (on the outside)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

The green graph is narrower than \(f(x)=x^2\). It must have a coefficient that is larger than the coefficient of \(x^2\). The green graph is \(f(x)=5x^2\).

The blue graph is wider than \(f(x)=x^2\). It must have a coefficient that is smaller than the coefficient of \(x^2\). The blue graph is \(f(x)=\frac{1}{3}x^2\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.12.4: Representations of Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give your group a set of cards. Each card contains a graph or an equation.

  • Take turns with your partner to sort the cards into sets so that each set contains two equations and a graph that all represent the same quadratic function.
  • For each set of cards that you put together, explain to your partner how you know they belong together.
  • For each set that your partner puts together, listen carefully to their explanation. If you disagree, discuss your thinking and work to reach an agreement.

Once all the cards are sorted and discussed, record the equivalent equations, sketch the corresponding graph, and write a brief note or explanation about why the representations were grouped together.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Set 1: 
Standard Form: \(y=x^2-1\)
Factored Form: \(y=(x+1)(x-1)\)

Set 2:
Standard Form: \(y=x^2-4x\)
Factored Form: \(y=x(x-4)\)

Set 3:
Standard Form: \(y=x^2-5x+4\)
Factored Form: \(y=(x-1)(x-4)\)

Set 4:
Standard Form: \(y=x^2-4x+4\)
Factored Form: \(y=(x-2)^2\)

page.title: 7.12.4: Self Check
page.contents:
Examine the graph below.

Which function matches the graph?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The zeros for this function are 2 and -1. The \(x\)-values that make the factors 0 are the zeros on the graph. The answer is \(f(x) = (x - 2)(x + 1)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The values \(x=-2\) and \(x=1\) will make each function equal 0. They are also zeros on the graph.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The zeros for this function are -2 and -1. The \(x\)-values that make the factors 0 are the zeros on the graph. The answer is \(f(x) = (x - 2)(x + 1)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The zeros for this function are 2 and 1. The \(x\)-values that make the factors 0 are the zeros on the graph. The answer is \(f(x) = (x - 2)(x + 1)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.12.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Matching Quadratic Functions and Their Graphs

Below is a quadratic function represented in standard form, factored form, and with a graph.

Standard Form: \(f(x)=x^2+2x-8\)
Factored Form: \(f(x) = (x + 4)(x - 2)\)

Notice the factored form helps find the zeros: \(x = -4\) and \(x = 2\).

The factored form gives the zeros since the zeros (\(x\)-intercepts) are located where each factor equals 0.

The standard form, \(f(x)=x^2+2x-8\), helps give the \(y\)-intercept. The \(y\)-intercept occurs when \(x = 0\). Here, \(f(0) = -8\). On the graph, the \(y\)-intercept is \((0, -8)\).

Try It: Matching Quadratic Functions and Their Graphs

Given the graph below and its function in standard form and factored form, identify all intercepts.

Standard form: \(f(x)=x^2-x-6\)
Factored form: \(f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 2)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the intercepts with the information provided:

The graph and the factored form help give the \(x\)-intercepts. They occur where the factors of the factored form equal 0, at \(x = -2\) and \(x = 3\). On the graph, these are where the graph crosses the \(x\)-axis, at the points \((-2, 0)\) and \((3, 0)\).

The \(y\)-intercept can be found with standard form when \(x=0\) in \(f(x)=x^2-x-6\). So \(y = -6\).
Notice on the graph, the \(y\)-intercept, where the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis, is at \((0, -6)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.12.5: Identifying Graphs of Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here are graphs that represent three quadratic functions, defined by:

\(f(x)=x^2-4\)
\(g(x)=1-x^2\)
\(h(x)=x^2+4\)


​ ​
  1. Which graph represents the equation \(f(x)=x^2-4\)?

Correct! Blue Graph B because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-4)\) and the graph opens upward.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Blue Graph B because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-4)\) and the graph opens upward.

​
  1. Which graph represents the equation \(g(x)=1-x^2\)?

Correct! Black Graph C because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,1)\) and the graph opens downward.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Black Graph C because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,1)\) and the graph opens downward.

​ ​
  1. Which graph represents the equation \(h(x)=x^2+4\)?

Correct! Green Graph A because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,4)\) and the graph opens upward.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Green Graph A because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,4)\) and the graph opens upward.


  1. Which part of the equation tells us that Graph C opens downward?

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=1-x^2\) is the equation. The negative coefficient of \(x^2\) makes the graph open downward.

page.title: 7.12.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Choose the quadratic equation that is represented by the graph.

Correct! The graph represents \(y=x^2-3\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-3)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2-3\). The graph represents \(y=x^2-3\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-3)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose the quadratic equation that is represented by the graph.

Correct! The graph represents \(y=x^2\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,0)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2\). The graph represents \(y=x^2\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,0)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose the quadratic equation that is represented by the graph.

Correct! The graph represents \(y=x^2+7\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,7)\) and the coefficient of the term \(y=x^2+7\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2+7\). The graph represents \(y=x^2+7\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,7)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose the quadratic equation that is represented by the graph.

Correct! The graph represents \(y=x^2+5\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,5)\) and the coefficient of the term \(y=x^2+5\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2+5\). The graph represents y=x2+5 because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,5)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The following two equations are equivalent.

factored form \(y=(x+2)(x+3)\) 
standard form \(y=x^2+5x+6\) 

  1. Which equation helps find the \(x\)-intercepts most efficiently?

Correct! The equation written in factored form \(y=(x+2)(x+3)\) because the factors in the expression allow us to see when the expression is 0.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.12.2–7.12.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is factored form. The equation written in factored form \(y=(x+2)(x+3) \) because the factors in the expression allow us to see when the expression is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which equation helps find the \(y\)-intercept most efficiently?

Correct! The equation written in standard form \(y=x^2+5x+6\) because the constant term shows us the \(y\)-intercept.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.12.2–7.12.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is standard form. The equation written in standard form \(y=x^2+5x+6\) because the constant term shows us the \(y\)-intercept. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. There are three equations represented on this graph:

\(y=x^2\) (black graph, at the top, opening upward)
\(y=x^2-4\)
\(y=-x^2+5\)

Use the graph to answer questions a and b.

  1. Which graph represents the equation \(y=x^2-4\)?

Correct! The blue graph represents \(y=x^2-4\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-4)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is blue graph (in the middle, opening upward). The blue graph represents \(y=x^2-4\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-4)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a positive 1, so the graph should open upward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which graph represents the equation \(y=-x^2+5\)?

Correct! The green graph represents \(y=-x^2+5\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,5)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a negative 1, so the graph should open downward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is green graph (at the bottom, opening downward). The green graph represents \(y=-x^2+5\) because the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,5)\) and the coefficient of the term \(x^2\) is a negative 1, so the graph should open downward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select two equations whose graphs have a positive \(y\)-intercept.

Correct! \(y=(x-1)^2\), \(y=(x+1)(x+2)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.12.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are: \(y=(x-1)^2\), \(y=(x+1)(x+2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which function represents the graph of \(f(x)=x^2\) shifted 5 units to the right?

Correct! The function is \(f(x)=(x-5)^2\) because subtracting 5 from \(x\) shifts the graph to the right 5 units.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(f(x)=(x-5)^2\). Subtracting 5 from \(x\) shifts the graph to the right 5 units. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select three equations whose graphs open downward.

Correct! \(y=1-x^2\), \(y=-(x-1)^2\), \(y=(1-x)(x+2)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.12.2 and activity 7.12.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are: \(y=1-x^2\), \(y=-(x-1)^2\), \(y=(1-x)(x+2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which curve is the narrowest?

Correct! The function is \(f(x)=(3x)^2\) is the narrowest because multiplying x by a value greater than 1 makes the curve grow faster. \((3x)^2 =9x^2\) , so \(f(x)=(3x)^2\) is the narrowest curve.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(f(x)=(3x)^2\). Multiplying \(x^2\) by a value greater than 1 makes the curve narrower. \((3x)^2 =9x^2\) , so \(f(x)=(3x)^2\) is the narrowest curve. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which equation is represented by the graph?

Correct! The graph represents \(y=-{(x-4)}^2+4\) because the graph is moved 4 units right and 4 units up and the squared term is multiplied by negative 1, so the graph should open downward.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.12.2–7.12.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \(y=-{(x-4)}^2+4\). The graph represents \(y=-{(x-4)}^2+4\) because the graph is moved 4 units right and 4 units up and the squared term is multiplied by negative 1, so the graph should open downward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which equation is represented by the graph?

Correct! The graph represents \(y=(x+2)^2+3\) because the graph is moved 2 units left and 3 units up and the squared term is multiplied by positive 1, so the graph should open upward.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.12.2–7.12.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=(x+2)^2+3\). The graph represents \(y=(x+2)^2+3\) because the graph is moved 2 units left and 3 units up and the squared term is multiplied by positive 1, so the graph should open upward. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.12.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain how the \(a\) and \(c\) in \(ax^2+bx+c\) affect the graph of the equation.
  • Explain how graphs, tables, and equations that represent the same quadratic function are related.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.12.1: Using Coefficients and Constant Terms to Identify Graphs of Linear Equations
    • In this activity, you matched three linear equations with their graphs by comparing slopes and \(y\)-intercepts.
  • 7.12.2: Transformations with Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you explored how transformations affect the graphs of quadratic functions.
    • 7.12.2: Self Check
    • 7.12.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.12.3: Understanding the Behaviors of a Graph in Relation to Its Quadratic Expression
    • In this activity, you examined the values in tables and how the values from a quadratic expression affect its graph.
    • 7.12.3: Self Check
    • 7.12.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.12.4: Representations of Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you used the standard form and factored form of quadratic functions as well as their graphs to identify intercepts to match the equivalent forms and their graphs.
  • 7.12.4: Self Check
    • 7.12.4: Additional Resources
  • 7.12.5: Identifying Graphs of Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you matched the graphs of quadratic functions with their equations.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.12.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
